result.markdown:
---
title: "Class 10: Halloween mini project"
author: "Ashley Mazon (PID: A17478903)"
format: pdf
toc: TRUE 
---

## Background 

As it is nearly Hallowneen and the halfway point in the quarter let's do a mini project to help us figure out the best candy! 

Out come from the 538 website and is available as a CSV file: 





::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
candy <- read.csv("candy-data.txt", row.names = 1)
head(candy)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
             chocolate fruity caramel peanutyalmondy nougat crispedricewafer
100 Grand            1      0       1              0      0                1
3 Musketeers         1      0       0              0      1                0
One dime             0      0       0              0      0                0
One quarter          0      0       0              0      0                0
Air Heads            0      1       0              0      0                0
Almond Joy           1      0       0              1      0                0
             hard bar pluribus sugarpercent pricepercent winpercent
100 Grand       0   1        0        0.732        0.860   66.97173
3 Musketeers    0   1        0        0.604        0.511   67.60294
One dime        0   0        0        0.011        0.116   32.26109
One quarter     0   0        0        0.011        0.511   46.11650
Air Heads       0   0        0        0.906        0.511   52.34146
Almond Joy      0   1        0        0.465        0.767   50.34755
```


:::
:::




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(flextable)
flextable::flextable(head(candy,10))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}

> Q6. Is there any variable/column that looks to be on a different scale to the majority of the other columns in the dataset?

The winpercent is on a 0-100 scale and the rest are 0-1. 


> Q7. What do you think a zero and one represent for the candy$chocolate column?

zero means it doesn't contain any chocolate and one means that chocolate is present 

> Q8. Plot a histogram of winpercent values


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(ggplot2)

ggplot (candy) + 
  aes(x=winpercent) +
  geom_histogram(bins= 20)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](class-10-halloween-mini-project_files/figure-pdf/unnamed-chunk-9-1.pdf){fig-pos='H'}
:::
:::



> Q9. Is the distribution of winpercent values symmetrical?


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot (candy) + 
  aes(x=winpercent) +
  geom_density()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](class-10-halloween-mini-project_files/figure-pdf/unnamed-chunk-10-1.pdf){fig-pos='H'}
:::
:::

The distribution is not symmetrical as it is slightly skewed to the right. 


> Q10. Is the center of the distribution above or below 50%?


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
summary(candy$winpercent)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
  22.45   39.14   47.83   50.32   59.86   84.18 
```


:::
:::


The center of the distribution is below 50%, it is observed to peak around 40% due to a median of 47.83%. 

> Q11. On average is chocolate candy higher or lower ranked than fruit candy?

for chocolate: 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# 1. Find all chocolate candy in the dataset

choc.inds <- candy$chocolate == 1
# 2. Find their winpercent values 

choc.win <- candy[choc.inds, ]$winpercent
# 3. Calculate the mean of these values 

choc.mean <- mean(choc.win)
choc.mean
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 60.92153
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# 4-6. Do the same for fruity candy 
# 7. Compare mean winpercents of chocolate vs. fruity 
# 8. Pick the highest as the winner 
```
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mean(candy[candy$chocolate==1,]$winpercent)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 60.92153
```


:::
:::

for fruity: 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
fruit.inds <- candy$fruity == 1
fruit.win <- candy[fruit.inds, ]$winpercent
fruit.mean <- mean(fruit.win)
fruit.mean
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 44.11974
```


:::
:::




> Q12. Is this difference statistically significant?


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
t.test(choc.win, fruit.win)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Welch Two Sample t-test

data:  choc.win and fruit.win
t = 6.2582, df = 68.882, p-value = 2.871e-08
alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0
95 percent confidence interval:
 11.44563 22.15795
sample estimates:
mean of x mean of y 
 60.92153  44.11974 
```


:::
:::

The difference is statisically significant due to a low p value of 2.817e-08.

> Q15. Make a first barplot of candy ranking based on winpercent values.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot (candy) + 
  aes( winpercent, rownames(candy))+ 
  geom_col()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](class-10-halloween-mini-project_files/figure-pdf/unnamed-chunk-19-1.pdf){fig-pos='H'}
:::
:::

> Q16. This is quite ugly, use the reorder() function to get the bars sorted by winpercent?


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot (candy) + 
  aes( x=winpercent, 
       y=reorder(rownames(candy),winpercent)) + 
  geom_col()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](class-10-halloween-mini-project_files/figure-pdf/unnamed-chunk-20-1.pdf){fig-pos='H'}
:::
:::


Add some color based on the "type of candy" 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
my_cols <- rep("black", nrow(candy))

my_cols[as.logical(candy$chocolate)] = "chocolate"
my_cols[as.logical(candy$bar)] = "brown"
my_cols[as.logical(candy$fruity)] = "pink"
```
:::




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(candy) + 
  aes(winpercent, reorder(rownames(candy),winpercent)) +
  geom_col(fill=my_cols) 
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](class-10-halloween-mini-project_files/figure-pdf/unnamed-chunk-22-1.pdf){fig-pos='H'}
:::
:::





> Q17. What is the worst ranked chocolate candy?

The worst ranked chocolate candy is Sixlet. 

> Q18. What is the best ranked fruity candy?

The best ranked fruity candy is Starburst 


## Winpercent and Pricepercent 

A plot with both variables/columns winpercent and pricepercent 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(ggrepel)

my_cols[as.logical(candy$fruity)] <-"red"

ggplot(candy) + 
  aes(x= winpercent, y= pricepercent, label = rownames(candy)) + 
  geom_point(col=my_cols)+ 
  geom_text_repel(max.overlaps = 7)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Warning: ggrepel: 68 unlabeled data points (too many overlaps). Consider
increasing max.overlaps
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](class-10-halloween-mini-project_files/figure-pdf/unnamed-chunk-23-1.pdf){fig-pos='H'}
:::
:::


> Q19. Which candy type is the highest ranked in terms of winpercent for the least money - i.e. offers the most bang for your buck?

Reeses Miniatures 

>Q20. What are the top 5 most expensive candy types in the dataset and of these which is the least popular?



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ord <- order(candy$pricepercent, decreasing = TRUE)
head( candy[ord,c(11,12)], n=5 )
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
                         pricepercent winpercent
Nik L Nip                       0.976   22.44534
Nestle Smarties                 0.976   37.88719
Ring pop                        0.965   35.29076
Hershey's Krackel               0.918   62.28448
Hershey's Milk Chocolate        0.918   56.49050
```


:::
:::


Nik L Lip, Ring pop, Nestles Smarties, Hershey's Krackle, Hershey's Milk Chocolate. The least popular is Nik L Lip.  


## Exploring the correlation structures 

Now that we've explored the dataset a little, we'll see how the variables interact with each other... the corrplot package to plot a correlation matrix. 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(corrplot)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
corrplot 0.95 loaded
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
cij <- cor(candy) 
corrplot(cij)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](class-10-halloween-mini-project_files/figure-pdf/unnamed-chunk-25-1.pdf){fig-pos='H'}
:::
:::


> Q22. Examining this plot what two variables are anti-correlated (i.e. have minus values)?

Chocolate and Fruity 

> Q23. Similarly, what two variables are most positively correlated?

chocolate and bar 

## Principal Component Analysis 

The function to use is called `prcomp()` with an optional `scale=T/F` argument. 



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
pca <- prcomp(candy, scale =TRUE)
summary (pca) 
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Importance of components:
                          PC1    PC2    PC3     PC4    PC5     PC6     PC7
Standard deviation     2.0788 1.1378 1.1092 1.07533 0.9518 0.81923 0.81530
Proportion of Variance 0.3601 0.1079 0.1025 0.09636 0.0755 0.05593 0.05539
Cumulative Proportion  0.3601 0.4680 0.5705 0.66688 0.7424 0.79830 0.85369
                           PC8     PC9    PC10    PC11    PC12

```


:::
:::

Our main PCA result figure 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot (pca$x) + 
  aes(PC1,PC2, label = rownames(pca$x)) + 
  geom_point(col=my_cols) + 
  geom_text_repel(col=my_cols)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Warning: ggrepel: 48 unlabeled data points (too many overlaps). Consider
increasing max.overlaps
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](class-10-halloween-mini-project_files/figure-pdf/unnamed-chunk-27-1.pdf){fig-pos='H'}
:::
:::



 
We should also examine the variable "loadings" or contributions of the original variables to the new PCs


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(pca$rotation) + 
  aes(PC1, rownames(pca$rotation))+ 
  geom_col()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](class-10-halloween-mini-project_files/figure-pdf/unnamed-chunk-28-1.pdf){fig-pos='H'}
:::
:::


Interactive plots that can be zoomed on and "brushed" over can be made with the **plotly** package. It's output is interactive and will not render to PDF :(
